qas.question: In what year did the New Zealand governor-general last personally grant the royal assent in parliament?
Which country has not used the formal assention ceremony since the early 20th century?
Who are the leaders of each house given the responsibility of informing their group of the governor-generals actions?

answers.text: President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives

plausible_answers.text: formal ceremony of granting assent in parliament

qas.question: What has not been used regularly since the early 20th century in America?
In New Zealland, the governor-general has personally granted the Royal Assent since what year?
What type of ceremony is commonly used to grant assent in Australia?

plausible_answers.text: Speaker of the House of Representatives

qas.question: The governor-general of Australia sends messages to the Vice President of the Senate and whom to grant assent?

context: In <a1_0>Australia<a1_0/>, the <b3_0><b5_0>formal<b5_0/> ceremony of granting assent in parliament<b3_0/> has not been regularly used since the early 20th century. Now, the bill is sent to the governor-general's residence by the house in which it originated. The governor-general then signs the bill, sending messages to the <a2_0>President of the Senate and the <b6_0>Speaker of the House of Representatives<b6_0/><a2_0/>, who notify their respective houses of the governor-general's action. A similar practice is followed in New Zealand, where the governor-general has not personally granted the Royal Assent in parliament since <a0_0><b4_0>1875<b4_0/><a0_0/>.
